titleStmt.title: Campūrāmāyaṇa, Bhāratasāvitrī, Viṣṇusahasranāma and different other texts

repository.orgName: Bibliothèque nationale de France. Département des Manuscrits

summary.p: This is a multi text manuscript. It begins with the Campūrāmāyaṇa and ends in the middle of the Vanauṣadhivarga of the Amarakośa. The Campūrāmāyaṇa is a well-known text based on the story of Rāma. The Bhāratasāvitrī is a supplement to the Mahābhārata and Harivaṃśa. The order of the verses is different than the one available on sanskritdocuments.org.

The folios of the Raghuvaṃśa part in the manuscript are not in order; for example folio 50r has Raghuvaṃśa canto 6, verse 57, and verse number 21 on 50v. Verse 28 is on 51r and then again on 74r canto 2 begins. Between the 6th canto of the Raghuvaṃśa, the Bhāratasāvitrī is written. 49v-51r is Raghuvaṃśa canto 6. The beginning verse on 49v is 6.52 and 51r has 6.30. On 51v is Bhāratasāvitrī and then again the 6th canto. Then the 1st and 2nd canto of the Raghuvaṃśa are seen.

the Sadyojātamantra, the declension of Rāma and many other nominal paradigms, the Prāyaścittahoma, and the Amarakośa have been identified. There are some more unidentified texts before the Amarakośa:
On folio 93r-93v, the Rudrapañcakam,
On folio 94r, the Sadyojātamantra,
On 100v-104r, the Śivasaṅkalpastotra,
On 105v-106v, the Rudrānuvāk,
On folio 151, the declension of the noun rāma,
On 154v, the Prāyaścittahoma.

support.p: Thin Palm leaves are used as support.

supportDesc.foliation: Roman numbers are found in the left corners with pen or pencil. It looks like this numbering is old as the ink is faint.
supportDesc.condition: Fragile. Many folio broken at the edges or half broken. Text is damaged due to faint ink or worm-eaten folios. Sometimes white patches are found at the corners of the folio.

layoutDesc.layout: The declensions of nominal paradigms are written in three columns otherwise the manuscript is written in a single column. The Raghuvaṃśa verses are not in order.

handNote.desc: Very difficult to read and follow. Many folio are mixed and the text continuity is disturbed. The manuscript folios needs to be rearranged. There are multiple hands. Some folios have clean and broad letters, sometimes it is very untidy. Some folio are scribbled down.
